articleContentTranslated: "For all the children out there who dream of the impossible - you can do it," were the first words of the 35-year-old Briton after his 94th Grand Prix victory.

"I can't find words, thanks to everyone who worked on this in the team," said Hamilton fighting back tears. His thanks on an ‚Äúincredible journey‚Äù also went to his family, with whom he had dreamed of such successes from an early age.

‚ÄúI couldn't have done better,‚Äù was the comment by Mercedes Motorsport Director Toto Wolff over the radio. ‚ÄúA fantastic drive, that was really awesome.‚Äù And in fact, Hamilton's tenth Grand Prix win was in 14th place.

Season race a masterpiece. After a less confident performance than usual in qualifying, he only started from sixth place. In difficult conditions and due to initial problems, the old and new world champions did not let themselves be deterred and drove to another triumph with a perfect strategy.

Hamilton wins his seventh world title Lewis Hamilton has been a seven-time Formula 1 world champion since Sunday. The Mercedes driver won the Turkish Grand Prix in Istanbul and thus dignified level with the previous record holder Michael Schumacher.

Turbulent start on a wet track As in qualifying on Saturday, the wet track was a determining factor at the beginning of the race. Antonio Giovinazzi said goodbye to the gravel bed with his Alfa Romeo on the way to the starting grid, George Russell destroyed the front wing of his Williams while driving into the pit lane.

But both could take part in the race. Racing Point driver Lance Stroll then got off to a good start from his first pole position, while Max Verstappen in the Red Bull couldn't get away and fell from second to fifth place behind Vettel, who was storming forward.
There were also problems at Mercedes: Valtteri Bottas spun and had to line up again at the end of the field, Hamilton drove into the emergency exit after a few corners.

Stroll and his team-mate Perez, however, were able to pull away on the drying track. LAP 1/58 It's a sublime start for the Racing Points, but Bottas and Ocon both spin off at Turn 1 # TurkishGP üáπüá∑ # F1 pic.twitter.com/YWd92CZKq6‚Äî Formula 1 (@ F1) 15.
November 2020 Initial phase with numerous battles for positions After eight laps, the first drivers picked up the intermediate tires. Verstappen overtook Vettel and was third again.
On lap 16, Hamilton also set out to attack Vettel. However, the world champion had problems and had to let Alexander Albon pass in return.
A little later, the Red Bull driver also took fourth place from Vettel. Verstappen maneuver goes wrong On lap 19, Verstappen was too impatient when trying to overtake second-placed Perez.
The Dutchman got on the slippery track barrier and spun. Although he was able to keep the car on the track, he damaged his tires and had to pit.

Instead of second, he was suddenly only eighth. He also got into trouble because he had crossed the blocking line after the pit lane. World champion works his way forward As a result, events on the track calmed down for some time, although Albon, who was so often scolded at Red Bull, put pressure on Perez, but couldn't break the Racing Point duo at the top either.
The DRS system was then approved for the first time by the race management just halfway through the race. In the World Cup duel, Hamilton had fewer problems than initially on the track.
The world champion was stuck in fifth place, but Bottas was only in 16th place. But then Vettel completed a pit stop and Albon turned - Hamilton was already third.

On lap 37, after Leader Stroll had just pitted, Hamilton and DRS also overtook Perez and led the Grand Prix for the first time. Stroll comes under pressure After a very strong first half of the race, Stroll made himself felt again.
Not quite as the Canadian had imagined, however. When attacking fourth-placed Vettel, he had to go a long way and instead let Leclerc pass.

A little later, Albon and Sainz also passed the Pole man. It went in the other direction for Leclerc. The Monegasse, who started twelfth, not only overtook his Ferrari team-mate, but a little later also Verstappen and was third for the first time.

Bottas, however, experienced bitter minutes, the Finn had to be lapped by Hamilton twelve laps before the end. In the very last corner, Vettel passed Leclerc. Hamilton makes Istanbul premiere A look at the history books shows how superior Hamilton is: never before has a driver won in Turkey who does not start from the front row was.
The Pole man was almost always the race winner. From second place only Jenson Button (2009) and Hamilton (2010) had won. The Briton succeeded from sixth on the grid.

Sebastian Vettel was also able to look forward to a premiere. The German finished on the podium for the first time this season in one of his last races for Ferrari at the Turkish Grand Prix in Istanbul
